title: Telica
meta_title: Telica — Eruption History, Height, Type & Facts | VolcanoAtlas
meta_description: Telica is a 1,036 m active stratovolcano in Nicaragua with 53 recorded eruptions. Full eruption history, current status, hazards, and visitor guide.

quick_answer.what: Telica is an active stratovolcano complex rising to 1,036 m (3,399 ft) in northwestern Nicaragua, and is one of the most frequently active volcanoes in Central America.
quick_answer.status: Active — erupting in 2025, with near-continuous low-level activity over recent decades. Monitored by INETER.
quick_answer.famous_for: Being one of Nicaragua's most persistently active volcanoes, with 53 recorded eruptions since the 16th century and a continuously degassing crater accessible to visitors.
quick_answer.danger_level: Moderate — surrounded by agricultural communities; frequent ash emissions and occasional larger explosions threaten nearby villages and the city of León (~200,000 people, ~25 km away).

key_facts_box.region: Cordillera de los Maribios, León Department
key_facts_box.tectonic_setting: Subduction zone — Cocos Plate beneath Caribbean Plate, continental crust (>25 km)
key_facts_box.population_at_risk: Tens of thousands in surrounding communities; ~200,000 in León
key_facts_box.summit_crater: 700 m wide double crater; southern crater 120 m deep, source of recent eruptions
key_facts_box.geothermal_area: Hervideros de San Jacinto — boiling mud pots and fumaroles SE of volcano

overview.content: Telica (Spanish: Volcán Telica) is an active stratovolcano complex rising to 1,036 m (3,399 ft) in the Cordillera de los Maribios of northwestern Nicaragua, and is one of the most frequently active volcanoes in Central America. With 53 recorded eruptions since the Spanish colonial period began in the 16th century, Telica has erupted with remarkable persistence — averaging approximately one eruption every 9–10 years, though in recent decades the frequency has increased to near-continuous low-level activity. The volcano group consists of several interlocking cones and vents aligned along a NW–SE trend, including the main Telica cone, the eroded and forested Santa Clara volcano at the southwestern end, and El Listón immediately to the east. Telica's steep-sided cone is truncated by a 700 m-wide double crater, with the southern crater — 120 m deep — serving as the source of all recent eruptions. The volcano sits above the subduction zone where the Cocos Plate dives beneath the Caribbean Plate, the same tectonic engine that powers the Ring of Fire's Central American Volcanic Arc, including neighbors like Cerro Negro and Momotombo. The Hervideros de San Jacinto, a prominent geothermal area with boiling mudpots and fumaroles southeast of Telica, is a popular tourist attraction and site of geothermal energy exploration. Telica is monitored by INETER and poses ongoing hazards to surrounding agricultural communities and the city of León, approximately 25 km to the southeast.

geology_and_formation.content:
Telica is part of the Central American Volcanic Arc, stretching approximately 1,500 km from Guatemala to Costa Rica, generated by the subduction of the Cocos Plate beneath the Caribbean Plate at the Middle America Trench. Subduction rates along this segment are approximately 7–8 cm per year, producing the magma that feeds Nicaragua's active volcanoes — one of the highest concentrations of active volcanism relative to land area in the world.

The Telica volcanic group consists of several interlocking cones with a general NW alignment, built upon Tertiary volcanic basement. Santa Clara, the eroded cone at the southwestern end, produced eruptions recorded during the 16th-century Spanish colonial period, though its deeply eroded crater has been covered by forest throughout modern times — these early eruptions may actually have originated from Telica. The main Telica cone has a steep, unvegetated upper profile truncated by a 700 m-wide double crater. The southern crater is 120 m deep and contains the active vent system. El Listón, immediately east, has several nested craters. Telica's basaltic to picritic basalt composition reflects relatively primitive magma reaching the surface — fluid, gas-rich, and capable of both effusive and explosive eruptions. The geothermal system beneath Telica and the nearby Hervideros de San Jacinto fumarole field indicate substantial heat flow and hydrothermal circulation beneath the volcanic complex.

eruption_history_overview.content: Telica's documented eruptive history spans nearly 500 years, beginning with records from the early Spanish colonial period. The 53 eruptions in the Smithsonian database include a VEI 4 event in 1529 — the largest recorded eruption — along with numerous VEI 1–2 events and a handful of VEI 3 eruptions. The 16th century records describe significant explosive activity, though whether some eruptions originated from Santa Clara or Telica is debated. The 20th century was exceptionally active, with eruptions recorded in almost every decade from the 1920s onward. The period from 1927 through 1951 saw frequent activity, as did the 1960s–1980s. Since the 1990s, Telica has been in a state of near-continuous unrest, with eruptions in 1994, 1999–2000, 2001, 2002, 2004–2008, 2011, 2013, 2015–2016, 2018, 2020–2022, and 2025. Most recent eruptions have been rated VEI 1–2, consisting of phreatic to phreatomagmatic explosions, ash emissions, and incandescent nighttime crater glow.

subsections.title: The 1529 Eruption (VEI 4) — Telica's Largest Recorded Event
subsections.content: The most powerful eruption in Telica's recorded history occurred in 1529, just years after the Spanish conquest of Nicaragua. This VEI 4 event produced a major explosive eruption with significant ashfall across the surrounding region. Spanish colonial records, though sparse, describe a powerful eruption that generated an ash column reaching well into the upper troposphere. The 1529 event is the only confirmed VEI 4 eruption at Telica and indicates the volcano is capable of eruptions far more powerful than the frequent VEI 1–2 events that characterize its modern activity. A VEI 3 eruption in 1527, just two years earlier, suggests a particularly active period. These early colonial records may conflate activity from Telica with the adjacent Santa Clara cone.

subsections.title: Mid-20th Century Activity (1927–1951) — Decades of Restlessness
subsections.content: From 1927 through 1951, Telica experienced nearly continuous volcanic unrest with eruptions recorded in 1927, 1928, 1929, 1934, 1937–1938, 1939, 1940, 1943–1944, 1946, 1948–1949, and 1951. These VEI 1–2 events were characterized by intermittent explosions from the summit crater, ash emissions, incandescent ejecta visible at night, and periodic ashfall on surrounding communities. The cumulative impact on local agriculture was significant, as repeated ashfall episodes damaged crops and contaminated water sources. This multi-decade active phase cemented Telica's reputation as one of Nicaragua's most persistently active volcanoes.

subsections.title: The 2015 Eruptions (VEI 2) — Explosions and Ashfall
subsections.content: Telica produced notable explosive activity in 2015, with two distinct eruptive episodes. In September 2015, a series of explosions from the southern crater ejected incandescent material and generated ash plumes reaching several kilometers above the summit. Ashfall was reported in communities downwind, and INETER raised the alert level. A second episode later in 2015 continued into 2016. These eruptions disrupted daily life in nearby villages and prompted temporary evacuations from the most exposed communities. The 2015 events were part of the broader pattern of near-continuous activity characterizing Telica since the 1990s.

subsections.title: 2020–2025 — Ongoing Persistent Activity
subsections.content: Telica has continued its persistent eruptive behavior through the early 2020s. VEI 1 eruptions were recorded in 2020 and 2021–2022, maintaining the pattern of frequent small explosions, gas emissions, and minor ashfall. In 2025, two eruptions have been confirmed (VEI 1), underscoring Telica's status as one of Central America's most continuously active volcanoes. The crater continues to degas vigorously, and incandescent glow is frequently visible at night, indicating magma or very hot material persists at shallow depth within the conduit.

current_status_and_monitoring.content:
Telica is currently in an active eruptive state, with confirmed eruptions in 2025. INETER monitors the volcano using seismometers, visual observation stations, and satellite data. The volcano produces frequent volcanic earthquakes, tremor, and degassing events. SO2 emissions from the crater are persistent and significant, contributing to regional air quality concerns.

The southern summit crater is continuously fuming, and incandescent glow is often visible at night from surrounding areas. INETER maintains a volcanic alert system and can issue evacuation orders for the most exposed communities. The persistence of shallow heat, active degassing, and frequent minor explosions indicates that Telica's magmatic plumbing system is continuously fed and eruptive activity at some level is likely to continue for the foreseeable future.

hazards_and_risk_assessment.content:
Telica poses several hazards to the surrounding population. The most common threat is ashfall from frequent explosive eruptions. While individual VEI 1–2 events produce relatively thin ash deposits, the cumulative impact on agriculture — a critical economic sector in this part of Nicaragua — is significant. Repeated ashfall damages crops (particularly coffee, corn, and beans), contaminates water supplies, and causes respiratory problems.

Ballistic projectiles are ejected during explosions and pose lethal hazard within 1–2 km of the crater. Larger eruptions (VEI 3–4, which are within Telica's demonstrated capability) could produce pyroclastic flows, more extensive ashfall reaching León (population ~200,000, approximately 25 km away), and potential lahars during the rainy season. Nicaragua's volcanic emergency response infrastructure is limited, and the agricultural communities closest to Telica have limited resources for evacuation and recovery. The Hervideros de San Jacinto geothermal area, frequently visited by tourists, lies within the broader volcanic hazard zone.

geography_and_physical_description.content:
Telica is a moderately-sized stratovolcano complex in the Cordillera de los Maribios, a NW–SE trending volcanic chain in northwestern Nicaragua. The main cone rises to 1,036 m (3,399 ft), with steep, unvegetated upper slopes contrasting with forested lower flanks and the eroded, forest-covered Santa Clara cone to the southwest. The summit is truncated by a 700 m-wide double crater. The southern crater, 120 m deep, is the source of all recent eruptive activity and continuously emits volcanic gases.

El Listón, a parasitic cone immediately east, features several nested craters. The surrounding landscape is a mosaic of agricultural land (cattle ranching, corn, beans, coffee), tropical dry forest, and volcanic terrain. The Hervideros de San Jacinto, located southeast of Telica, is a prominent geothermal field with boiling mud pots, fumaroles, and hot springs. The nearest major city, León — a UNESCO World Heritage colonial city and Nicaragua's second-largest urban center — lies approximately 25 km to the southeast in the Pacific lowlands.

climate_and_global_impact.content: Telica's characteristically small eruptions (VEI 1–2) have no measurable global climate impact. Even the VEI 4 eruption of 1529 was modest on a global scale. The volcano's primary atmospheric contribution is persistent degassing, which releases sulfur dioxide and other volcanic gases into the regional troposphere. This chronic degassing contributes to vog (volcanic smog) conditions downwind and can affect local air quality. In the broader context of Central American volcanism, Telica's emissions are a small fraction of the total volcanic gas output from the arc, which also includes major degassers like Masaya and Fuego.

cultural_significance.content:
Telica holds cultural significance within Nicaraguan identity as one of the country's most recognizable and active volcanoes. The Cordillera de los Maribios has been central to the cultural landscape of western Nicaragua since pre-Columbian times, when the Chorotega and Nicarao peoples inhabited the region. Spanish colonists documented Telica's eruptions from the earliest years of contact, making it one of the first volcanoes in the Americas to enter the European written record.

The Hervideros de San Jacinto geothermal area, associated with Telica's deep heat source, has become one of Nicaragua's most popular natural attractions. Nicaragua markets its volcanoes actively as tourism assets, and Telica's accessible, photogenic, fuming crater contributes to this branding. For the rural communities living on Telica's flanks, the volcano is both a source of fertile volcanic soil that sustains agriculture and a persistent threat that shapes daily life.

visiting_and_tourism.content:
Telica is one of Nicaragua's most popular volcanoes for tourism, known for its accessible crater with visible fumarolic activity and — on clear nights — incandescent glow from the hot interior. The standard hike to the crater rim takes approximately 1.5–2 hours from the trailhead near the village of San Jacinto, ascending through farmland and scrubby forest to the barren volcanic summit. The crater rim offers dramatic views into the 120 m-deep southern crater.

Sunset and nighttime hikes are particularly popular, as the crater glow becomes vividly visible after dark. Local guides can be arranged through tour operators in León. The Hervideros de San Jacinto geothermal field is a separate popular attraction, with boardwalks allowing visitors to observe boiling mud pots and fumaroles. Visitors should be aware that Telica is actively erupting and conditions change rapidly — the crater area can experience sudden small explosions, and SO2 concentrations near the rim can be hazardous. Always check INETER alert status before visiting.

nearby_volcanoes.content: Telica sits within the Cordillera de los Maribios, one of Central America's most volcanically dense chains. Cerro Negro (728 m), a young basaltic cinder cone famous for 'volcano boarding,' lies approximately 20 km to the southeast. San Cristóbal (1,745 m), Nicaragua's tallest volcano, stands roughly 30 km to the northwest. Momotombo (1,297 m), overlooking Lake Managua, is located approximately 60 km to the southeast. Masaya, a persistently active caldera with a lava lake, lies near Managua. In total, Nicaragua hosts 13 Holocene volcanoes along the Central American Volcanic Arc, giving this small nation one of the highest volcano-per-area ratios in the world.

etymology.content: The name 'Telica' is derived from the Nahuatl language, spoken by the pre-Columbian peoples of the region. The exact meaning is debated, but it may relate to 'Tecilli' (associated with lords or rulers) or local indigenous place names. The nearby town of Telica shares the name. The adjacent Santa Clara cone was named by Spanish colonists.

facts: Telica has produced 53 recorded eruptions since 1527 — nearly 500 years of documented volcanic activity, one of the longest eruptive records in Central America.
The VEI 4 eruption of 1529 is the largest in Telica's history, occurring just years after the Spanish conquest of Nicaragua.
Since the late 1990s, Telica has been in a state of near-continuous eruptive unrest, with eruptions confirmed in most years from 1999 through 2025.
The Hervideros de San Jacinto, a geothermal field with boiling mud pots and fumaroles southeast of Telica, is one of Nicaragua's most visited natural attractions.
Telica's southern summit crater is 120 m deep and produces visible incandescent glow at night — a dramatic sight for the sunset/nighttime hikers who visit the rim.
The city of León, a UNESCO World Heritage site and Nicaragua's second-largest city, lies just 25 km from Telica's summit.
Nicaragua has one of the highest volcano-to-land-area ratios in the world, with 13 Holocene volcanoes in a country the size of Mississippi.
Telica's persistent SO2 degassing contributes to chronic air quality issues (vog) in the surrounding communities during periods of increased activity.
Sixteenth-century eruptions attributed to Santa Clara — the forested cone at Telica's southwestern end — may actually have originated from Telica itself.
Geothermal exploration near Telica has assessed the volcano's heat source as a potential energy resource for Nicaragua, one of Central America's least electrified nations.
The 20th century alone accounts for 31 of Telica's 53 recorded eruptions — a dramatic acceleration compared to earlier centuries.

faqs.question: Is Telica still active?
faqs.answer: Yes, Telica is one of the most persistently active volcanoes in Central America. It has been in a state of near-continuous eruptive unrest since the late 1990s, with confirmed eruptions in 2025. The southern summit crater continuously emits volcanic gases and frequently produces small explosive eruptions, ash emissions, and visible incandescent glow at night. INETER (Nicaragua's territorial studies institute) monitors the volcano and maintains an alert system. Given the volcano's 53 eruptions over nearly 500 years, continued activity is considered a near-certainty.

faqs.question: Can you hike Telica volcano?
faqs.answer: Yes, Telica is one of Nicaragua's most popular volcano hikes. The standard route from the trailhead near San Jacinto village takes approximately 1.5–2 hours to reach the crater rim at 1,036 m. Sunset and nighttime hikes are especially popular because the crater's incandescent glow becomes vividly visible after dark. Local guides can be arranged through tour operators in León, located 25 km away. However, because Telica is actively erupting, conditions can change rapidly — sudden small explosions and hazardous SO2 gas concentrations near the rim are real dangers. Always check INETER alert status before visiting.

faqs.question: How dangerous is Telica?
faqs.answer: Telica poses a moderate hazard level. Its frequent VEI 1–2 eruptions produce ashfall that damages crops, contaminates water, and causes respiratory problems in surrounding agricultural communities. Ballistic projectiles ejected during explosions are lethal within 1–2 km of the crater. Telica's demonstrated VEI 4 capability (1529) means larger eruptions producing pyroclastic flows and heavy ashfall reaching León (~200,000 people, 25 km away) are possible, though rare. Nicaragua's volcanic emergency infrastructure is limited. For hikers, the active crater rim presents immediate hazards from sudden explosions and toxic gases.

faqs.question: What is the Hervideros de San Jacinto?
faqs.answer: The Hervideros de San Jacinto is a geothermal field located southeast of Telica volcano, featuring boiling mud pots, fumaroles, and hot springs. It is one of Nicaragua's most popular natural attractions, visited by both domestic and international tourists. The geothermal activity is powered by the same magmatic heat source that drives Telica's volcanic eruptions. Boardwalks allow visitors to safely observe the bubbling mud pools and steaming vents. The site has also been investigated as a potential source of geothermal energy. It is located near the village of San Jacinto, easily accessible from the city of León.

faqs.question: What type of volcano is Telica?
faqs.answer: Telica is classified as a stratovolcano complex, meaning it consists of several interlocking volcanic cones and vents rather than a single cone. The complex includes the main Telica cone, the older and eroded Santa Clara volcano to the southwest, and El Listón to the east. The main Telica cone is truncated by a 700 m-wide double crater, with the 120 m-deep southern crater being the source of all recent eruptive activity. Telica's basaltic composition makes its eruptions less viscous and generally less explosive than andesitic stratovolcanoes, though it has produced a VEI 4 eruption (1529).

faqs.question: When was Telica's biggest eruption?
faqs.answer: Telica's largest recorded eruption occurred in 1529, rated VEI 4 on the Volcanic Explosivity Index — just years after the Spanish conquest of Nicaragua. This eruption produced a major explosive event with significant ashfall across the region. A VEI 3 eruption had occurred just two years earlier in 1527. Since then, Telica's eruptions have been predominantly VEI 1–2, making the 1529 event an outlier in the modern record. However, its occurrence demonstrates that Telica is capable of eruptions significantly more powerful than its typical frequent, small events.

faqs.question: How far is Telica from León?
faqs.answer: Telica's summit lies approximately 25 km (16 mi) northwest of the city of León, Nicaragua's second-largest urban area with a population of roughly 200,000. León serves as the main tourist base for visiting Telica, with tour operators offering guided hikes to the crater rim. The drive from León to the Telica trailhead takes approximately 45 minutes. During larger eruptions, ashfall from Telica can reach León, and the city falls within the potential hazard zone for a VEI 3–4 event.

schema_data.name: Telica
schema_data.description: Active stratovolcano complex in northwestern Nicaragua with 53 eruptions since 1527
